awd_titl_txt: Conference: NSF Symposium on Undergraduate Research - 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides travel support for undergraduate student participation in the Symposium on Undergraduate Research. This Symposium will be held at the annual meeting of the American Physical Society Division of Laser Science (DLS), in conjunction with the annual Frontiers in Optics (FiO) meeting of Optica. The conference program includes many of the research topics central to Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics. The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in laser science acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology. 

The meeting is scheduled to be held in Tacoma, WA on October 9 2023. It offers an opportunity for undergraduate students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The twenty-third annual DLS Symposium on Undergraduate Research at LS-XXXIX was held on Monday, 9 October, 2023 in Tacoma, WA. The schedule was similar to that of last year in Rochester in many ways, especially having one single large ballroom for all the activities.  All the technical details, as well as management of our sessions, were again handled by the Optica (formerly OSA) meetings department, and everything worked out with no major snags or glitches, even though there were several personnel changes. The 2023 Symposium began with welcoming dinner on Sunday evening, 8 October, in the Indochine  Restaurant that is just a few blocks from the Holiday Inn Express Hotel where most of the students were housed.

Monday morning was unscheduled, and some of the students used the time to mount their posters and become further acquainted with one another.  Our Symposium events began at noon in the Chambers Ballroom, and once again were joined by students from the “Amplify Optics Immersion” program organized by Optica.  The program is focused on bringing together Black physics and engineering undergraduate or graduate students to explore the research and career opportunities within optics and photonics at our annual meeting. It was run by Marcia Lesky and she suggested that there is common ground between that program and our symposium.  After considering several ways to join the groups, it was decided to bring them together at lunch on Monday, 9 October. 

It was a buffet lunch in the Chambers Ballroom, and it was a big success.  The students mixed up their tables and even met with a delegation from Nigeria as well as many different states.  There were plenty of sandwiches and fruits, and everything was fresh. The students were addressed by Marcia Lesky and also by Prof. Lou DiMauro  who is a very close collaborator with this year’s Nobel Laureate Pierre Agostini from Ohio State. They had extended, lively conversations among themselves and we’re confident that many useful connections were formed.  We were introduced to Sarah Moore from Optica who also joined us for dinner that evening. 

The scientific events began with the poster session, also in the Chambers Ballroom.  The setup was spacious and well lit, and the multiple conversations and presentations were active and lively including immersion students joined (see photo). The session was presided by Peter Delfyett Univ. of Central Florida.  The session included 36 papers whose abstracts were published in an eight-page program (copy attached) and ran from 1:00 to 3:00.  Many conference attendees come over to meet the students and talk with them about their work. 

It was gratifying that these very young scientists could give their first presentations at a professional meeting, and it was clearly a memorable event for them. Eighteen of this year's presenters were female, an impressive representation of 33 %.  Many of the students remained at the meeting one or more extra days to hear talks or visit exhibits. Some were thrilled to meet famous and/or highly visible scientists, including the authors of some of their textbooks.  Judging from the enthusiastic notes that accompanied their final expense reports, the student participants will surely remember this opportunity throughout their professional lives.   Some of the comments were:

  • I thoroughly enjoyed the entire event. It was my first time ever participating in a conference, and It was a positive experience that makes me want to participate in more…
  • I am excited and privileged. Conferences like this motivate us to do more and learn more.
  • The undergraduate research symposium portion of the conference was stellar. I enjoyed getting to hear from each individual about their research. I did feel like it was a very long amount of time in the same room, however. In the future I think it would be nice to be able to split up a little bit more and move around. 
  • As a senior undergraduate student in physics who has, up until now, not had much professional experience in the field, it was an amazing opportunity for me to speak with both accomplished professionals and undergraduate students in my exact same position. It gave me a lot of insight into what my future might hold if I continue down this path and was also comforting in the sense that all of my peers were just as new to it as I was, but that we all shared a passion for our research…
  • Professionally and personally, I found it to be an amazing experience. It was my first time traveling alone - while I had assistance from my mentor, I handled much of the logistics on my own, …
